Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Carbon Limitation, Algal Ecology, and Greenhouse Gases: Can Algal Blooms Fight Climate Change?
Award.AbstractNarration:
The increasing frequency and magnitude of harmful algal blooms (HABs) is a global problem, exacerbated by rising temperatures and cultural eutrophication, and is most severe in regions experiencing rapid urbanization and agricultural development. The Taihu basin, China, is a poster child of this type of region and frequently experiences severe HABs, often dominated by the neurotoxin producing cyanobacteria of the genera Microcystis. While the overall duration and size of a bloom is limited by the supply of nitrogen and phosphorus, there is growing evidence that carbon (C) availability may also limit growth in some cases. The proposed research is a collaborative project with Prof. Guangwei Zhu (Nanjing Institute of Geography and Limnology) investigating the potential for C limitation, the role it may play in phytoplankton ecology, and possible implications for global C cycling. A diverse suite of tools, including stable isotopes, diagnostic photopigments, and other biogeochemical indicators will be used to better constrain the aforementioned processes. The proposed research will advance our understanding of the Taihu system, one that is a model for other heavily impacted ecosystems worldwide. HABs, like those common to Taihu, are complex events with diverse biogeochemical drivers and the potential for numerous environmental feedbacks, many of which are poorly understood. Results from this study will help determine the degree to which one of these drivers, C limitation, may affect the bloom size and dominance of potentially toxic HAB species in this environmentally and economically vital lake.

Inorganic C fixation during dense phytoplankton blooms can reach extremely high rates, removing dissolved CO2 faster than can be supplied by air-sea exchange and respiration. Species capable of assimilating inorganic C as bicarbonate (H2CO3) such as the toxin-producing Microcystis will therefore be at a competitive advantage when CO2 becomes limiting. In the proposed research, ?√ù13C of phytoplankton will be used as an indicator of C sources and acquisition strategies, while an analysis of photopigments by HPLC will be used to investigate the effects of C availability on phytoplankton ecology during the progression of a bloom in the hypereutrophic lake Taihu, China.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The increasing frequency and magnitude of harmful algal blooms (HABs) is a global problem, exacerbated by rising temperatures, cultural eutrophication, urbanization and agricultural development. Lake Taihu, China, a hypereutrophic, subtropical lake, is a poster child for this issue, and frequently experiences HABs dominated by potentially toxigenic cyanobacteria. This study investigates the impact of these HABs on the lake carbon (C) cycle at large, and the role of inorganic C supply on phytoplankton ecology. Water samples were collected on a dawn-noon-dusk schedule over the course of a month in northwestern Taihu. Stable C isotopes were quantified for both DIC and POC, along with dissolved gas concentrations, diagnostic phytopigments, and a variety of other biogeochemical parameters. Environmental conditions were highly variable over the course of the study, including 2 weeks of monsoon rains, episodic storms, and periods of relative calm. Hot, calm, and potentially CO2 limited conditions were associated with cyanobacterial dominance, while chlorophytes appeared to proliferate during and after storms. Over the study period, the lake was a net source of both CO2and CH4to the atmosphere. Diurnal cycles of production and respiration drove ∂13CDICand ∂13CPOCto vary between -4 and -9‰, and -20 and -30‰, respectively. Both measurements and subsequent modeling results demonstrate that enzymatic fractionation factors (εp) decreased with as pCO2 dropped, suggesting that at times, phytoplankton may have been limited by inorganic C availability. This is an important contribution to our understanding of the drivers of carbon cycling during large algal blooms, which are becoming more frequent as both temperature and nutrient loading increase.
